titleStmt.title: Three letters from Sir Thomas Fairfax his armie The one, from a gentleman residing there, to a worthy Member of the honourable House of Commons. Fully relating the manner of the late fight betweene Sir Thomas Fairfax, and Generall Gorings forces in Sutton-field neere Lamport, on Thursday last July 10. wherein the enemies whole army was routed, about 2000. Prisoners, 4000. armes, neere 2000. horse, and 40. colours taken, besides many horse and prisoners in the pursuit, and Goring and his scattered forces fled into Bridgewater. Also the particulars of the fight between Major General Massey's and the enemies forces, neere Ilmore, on Wednesday last, July 9. where he tooke 500. of the enemies horse, 200. prisoners, 2. majors, 6. captains, 9. colours, and 30. slaine on the place. Published by authority.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 13 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 6 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

titleStmt.title: Three letters from Sir Thomas Fairfax his armie The one, from a gentleman residing there, to a worthy Member of the honourable House of Commons. Fully relating the manner of the late fight betweene Sir Thomas Fairfax, and Generall Gorings forces in Sutton-field neere Lamport, on Thursday last July 10. wherein the enemies whole army was routed, about 2000. Prisoners, 4000. armes, neere 2000. horse, and 40. colours taken, besides many horse and prisoners in the pursuit, and Goring and his scattered forces fled into Bridgewater. Also the particulars of the fight between Major General Massey's and the enemies forces, neere Ilmore, on Wednesday last, July 9. where he tooke 500. of the enemies horse, 200. prisoners, 2. majors, 6. captains, 9. colours, and 30. slaine on the place. Published by authority.
titleStmt.author: S. J. aut

notesStmt.note: The second letter is signed and dated: Your affectionate friend, S.J. Lamport, 11. July, 1645. at 9 a clock at night.
Reproduction of original in the University of Illinois (Urbana-Champaign Campus). Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THREE LETTERS FROM Sir Thomas Fairfax HIS ARMIE.
The one, from a Gentleman re≈øiding there, to a worthy Member of the honourable Hou≈øe of Commons.

Fully relating the manner of the late Fight betweene Sir Thomas Fairfax, and Generall Gorings Forces in Sutton-field neere Lamport, on Thur≈øday la≈øt July 10. wherein the Enemies whole Army was routed, about 2000. Pri≈øoners, 4000. Armes, neere 2000. Hor≈øe, and 40. Colours taken, be≈øides many Hor≈øe and Pri≈øoners in the pur≈øuit, and Goring and his ≈øcattered Forces fled into Bridgewater.

Al≈øo the particulars of the Fight between Major General Ma≈ø≈øey's and the Enemies Forces, neere Ilmore, on Wedne≈øday la≈øt, July 9. where he tooke 500. of the Enemies Hor≈øe, 200. pri≈øoners, 2. Majors, 6. Captains, 9. Colours, and 30. ≈ølaine on the place.

div.head: A Letter from a Gentleman in the Army, to an Honourable Member of the Hou≈øe of Commons.
div.p:
IN my la≈øt I gave you an account of our affaires till ye≈øterday morning, and then I left Goring with his whole Army at Lamport; ≈øince then be plea≈øed to take notice of a ≈øhort relation of our actions. Ye≈øterday wee advanced to Sutton, drawing out that part of our Army, which we had, into Sutton fields, the re≈øt being 4500 at the lea≈øt, under the command of Major-Generall Ma≈ø≈øey, were on the other ≈øide of the river, and tho≈øe eight Regiments of Foot which wee had at Naesby field, were al≈øo quartered at Martoke; Ma≈ø≈øey advanced with his Hor≈øe and Dragoons, having the Foot to back him to North-Carreg, being ordered to ≈øtraiten the enemies quarters, and to hinder them from any plundring exerci≈øes. It ≈øeems 1500 of them being upon a de≈øigne out, and having no intelligence of his being in motion, were ≈øurprized in a carele≈ø≈øe po≈øture; Major-Generall Ma≈ø≈øey fell on them, took (as I take it) nine Colours, 200 pri≈øoners, and 250 Hor≈øe, ≈ølew about 30. Wee (in the meane time) were drawne up within a mile of Lamport, with tho≈øe Hor≈øe the Generall had with him, not knowing of his engagement, and there being three rivers betweene him and us, and the way without 12 miles march. The la≈øt night we quartered at Sutton, and this morning by three a clock drew out into Sutton-fields, having with us but ≈øeven Regiments of hor≈øe, viz. The Generals, formerly called Lievtenant-Generall Cromwells, Whaley's, Vermudens, Graves, Rich, Fleetwood, Butlers, which were not in all 2800 Hor≈øe; of Foot, we had all but the Musketiers of three Regiments, having ≈øent for
them the la≈øt night from Martoke. Early this morning the enemy appeared in the field, and about 7. of the clock they made them≈øelves Ma≈øters of a pa≈ø≈øe, which lay in the mid≈øt between our Body and theirs, had lined the hedges between us and them with at lea≈øt 2000 Musketiers, ≈øo that the pa≈ø≈øage to them was extraordinary dangerous, being ≈øo ≈øtraight that foure hor≈øes could not pa≈ø≈øe a bre≈øt, and that up to the belly in water. They lying ≈øo prepared, both in Flanks and Front to receive us; in this po≈øture they ≈øtood till nigh 11 of the clock, having in the interim ≈øent away mo≈øt of their Traine and Baggage, led Hor≈øes, and other Lumber, to Bridgewater, being re≈øolved to make good their Retreat thither, which they conceived they could, having ≈øuch an advantagious pa≈ø≈øe thither; we under≈øtanding their intentions by ≈øome Spies, and other Countrey-men, re≈øolved to charge them, and accordingly drew downe a commanded partie of Musketiers to beat them from the hedges, which was done with a gallant re≈øolution; advancing the ≈øame time with two Regiments of Hor≈øe into the Lane, all that we could draw up in Front was but a ≈øingle Troop, and that commanded by Major Bethell, the Enemy ≈øtanding ready with three Bodies of Hor≈øe, of about a thou≈øand to charge him. He with a ≈øingle Troop charged, and routed two of their Divi≈øions of about 400, received the charge of the third Divi≈øion both in Front and Flank, was ≈øomewhat over-borne at la≈øt, and enforced to retire to the Generals Regiment, which was about an hundred yards behind him: C. Desborow with the Generalls Troope ≈øheltred him by his Flank to rally, and charged up him≈øelfe with about 200 Hor≈øe of the Generals Regiment, di≈øper≈øt the Enemy, and ≈øet them all a running, gained freedome by it for all our Hor≈øe and Foot to draw into Bodies, ≈øent the Enemy running, not being able to endure. In the charge the Generall,
Lievtenant-Generall, and ≈øome other Officers upon the hill beholding the gallant charge, commended it for the mo≈øt excellent peece of ≈øervice that ever was in England, we had them in chace almo≈øt to Bridgewater, having put them to the cleere≈øt Rout that ever an Enemy was put to: what the number of the ≈ølaine be I cannot tell you, being ≈øcarce come from the chace: The pri≈øoners come in already are 900, and I beleeve there will come in as many as wil make 2000. 1200 Hor≈øe taken at lea≈øt: For Colours I am uncertaine, I dare ≈øay at lea≈øt 40, the Armes at lea≈øt 4000, two peeces of Ordnance I ≈øaw, and divers carriages of Ammunition, and to make it a compleat victorie, wee pur≈øued the Enemy thorow Lamport, having gained the Garri≈øon, and then they fired the Towne ju≈øt at the bridge to hinder the chace, yet we followed the victorie thorow the fire. The ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of this victorie mu≈øt needs be a≈øcribed next unto God, to the good conduct of the Generall and Cromwell, Cromwell following the chace thorow Lamport, where hee him≈øelfe went thorow the fire flaming on both ≈øides of him. The Enemy crie out they are utterly undone, and that the King mu≈øt now go for Ireland. Sir, this victorie was the more opportune, that had they ≈øtaid but three dayes longer, Goring would have had a re-inforcement of 6000 Hor≈øe and Foot from Greenvill and the King, they being tran≈øporting their Forces as fa≈øt as can be to Minehead, Watchead, and Uphill, there being 1500 that landed ad Uphill come to Bridgewater ye≈øterday. Sir, this is all at pre≈øent from

closer.dateline: Lamport July 10 ≈øeven a clock at night.

div.head: A Letter from an Officer in the Army, to his wife in London.

opener.salute: DEer wife, Salutation in the Lord, &c. who continues in multiplying favours upon his people.

div.p:
This day after our drawing into the field within two miles of Lamport, a pretty ≈øtrong Garri≈øon of the enemies. Our Army was ranged into a Battalia, and the Forlorn Hopes on each wing being drawne out and marched, the whole Army pre≈øently advanced, the enemy having ≈øecured a pa≈ø≈øage, which was the onely way for us to make through to fall on them; where we could not march above foure hor≈øe a bre≈øt, in which place the enemy did front, and flank us al≈øo on both ≈øides: when our Forlorns marched nigh them, (the Hill they ≈øtood on, they divided them≈øelves on, in ≈øeverall divi≈øions and ≈øquadrons of Hor≈øe and Foot) our Foot fired in Volleyes, and our Ordnance played ≈øo quick and ≈øure, that pre≈øently the enemy were put to a rout, and were as in a maze, not knowing what way to avoid the Cannon; yet all this while maintained the pa≈ø≈øage, which was in hot di≈øpute betweene them and us; yet at la≈øt, within an houre or thereabouts, we gained it, and ≈øent Hor≈øe to ≈øecond our Foot. One Major Bethell with his Troupe went on in the fir≈øt place, and was to go up a ≈øteepe hill to charge (and but his own Troupe) by the time he came neere: the Enemy came on in a va≈øt Body of Hor≈øe again≈øt them, and laid Musketiers in a hedge, which did flank him, and ≈øomwhat front him al≈øo, yet with ≈øuch gallantry he mannaged the charge, that they put the enemy to the rout, (all in that place) but pre≈øently a great fre≈øh ≈øupply came, that cau≈øed our fir≈øt party to retreat to the pa≈ø≈øage to our men, who played on the enemy, and cau≈øed them to retreat, and then our Hor≈øe and Foot marched on furiou≈øly,
and at the ≈øecond charge beat the enemy out of the field, put them to a rout, we killed on the ≈øeverall hils we ≈øtood on, and valleyes we fought in, not above 20. but in the pur≈øuit very many. There are already brought in nigh 1000. pri≈øoners, two Carriages of Ammunition, and two ≈ømall pieces, which were all they had in the field. They for≈øooke their Garri≈øon of Lamporne, and are gone towards Bridgewater. Ye≈øterday Major-Generall Ma≈ø≈øey went with about 7000. Hor≈øe, Dragoons, and Foot, on the other ≈øide of Lamport, skirmi≈øhed with the enemy, and took about 500. hor≈øe, thirty ≈ølain, and 200. taken, whereof two Majors, 6. Captaines, and nine Colours. I am in health, and all our friends, for ought I heare; I cannot particularize yet, for our men are not all returned from the pur≈øuit. The Kings partie here is quite routed, and I hope we ≈øhall ≈øuddenly drive them from having an Army in the field, and vi≈øit their Garri≈øons. God hath wonderfully appeared with his people who fir≈øt charged, that ≈øcarce ever any ≈øuch Charge was ≈øeen in England heretofore. The Generall and hone≈øt Cromwell behaved them≈øelves mo≈øt gallantly. I am in ha≈øt, and re≈øt,

closer.dateline: Lamport, 11. July, 1645. at 9. a clock at night.

div.head: A Letter from an Officer in the Armie to his brother in London, containing all the particulars of the fight between Major Generall Ma≈ø≈øey and the Enemie, Iuly 9.
div.p: MY love to you and my ≈øi≈øter, hoping you are in health as I am at writing hereof; I give the Lord prai≈øe for it, ye≈øterday about two in the afternoon, Major Gen. Ma≈ø≈øey fell upon 2000. of Gorings Hor≈øe in Ilmore, and a≈ø≈øoone as wee came in ≈øight they ran a way, and we pur≈øued them almo≈øt to their Garri≈øon of Lamport, we took neer 500. Hor≈øe and 200. Pri≈øoners, and ≈ølew about twentie: Then Sir Thomas Fairfax was at Long-Sutton within two miles of Lamport, this morning he drew forth into the Field, and Goring likewi≈øe drew forth of Lamport and tooke a pa≈ø≈øe and lined the hedges with Mu≈øketiers near 2000. and drew up a great Bodie of Hor≈øe, our Generall drew down towards him, and came up and charged him, and we were ingaged about two houres by parties, at la≈øt put the Enemie to a retreat into Lamport, and we fell on and the enemy ran out at the other end of the towne, and ≈øet both ≈øides of the ≈øtreets on fire, and burnt down about 20. hou≈øes, and ran away to Bridgewater, and ≈øent this morning and la≈øt night all their Carriages and Baggage, except two pieces of Ordnance, and two Carriages of Ammunition in the Town which we now po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe, we cha≈øed them ≈øix miles, tooke about 1000. pri≈øoners in the flight, and are now in pur≈øuit of them: The Lord follow us with ≈øucce≈ø≈øe and give us grace to returne glorie to God, for all his mercies extended towards us.

postscript.p: The Me≈ø≈øenger who ≈øtaied in the the Army two houres after the date of the≈øe Letters, relates that our men brought in Pri≈øoners and Hor≈øe all the while he was there: ≈øo that he beheves there were not le≈ø≈øe then 2500. Hor≈øe taken, and 2000. Foot pri≈øoners: that the Sommer≈øet≈øhire Club-men brought in divers of the enemies ≈øtraglers pri≈øoners, that he heard, that Lievtenant Generall Porter was taken.
